ArcFlow AI Enabled Cloud ERP Training & Support  
Welcome to the ArcFlow ERP Training Guide. This comprehensive manual is crafted to provide 
you with the essential knowledge and skills to effectively use the ArcFlow ERP system. It 
includes detailed walkthrough documents and instructional videos on each mo dule, as well as 
insights into the workflow dependencies between modules.  
Whether you are new to ERP systems or seeking to deepen your expertise in ArcFlow's advanced 
features, this guide will lead you through each module, showing you how to streamline business 
processes, enhance productivity, and achieve seamless integration ac ross all departments. Join 
us on this journey to master the tools and functionalities that will propel your organisations 
success.  
  
Self Paced Training Guides  
The training guide is organised into the various ArcFlow modules to facilitate easy navigation. 
Please select the dropdown menu to view the different sub -modules available. Once you have 
chosen a specific sub -module, you will be able to access detailed vid eos and comprehensive 
walkthrough documentation tailored to that sub -module, ensuring you have all the resources 
needed to master each aspect of the ArcFlow system. You can utilise the search bar at the top 
right of your screen to find specific training co ntent.

ArcFlow Real Time In -App Support  
ArcFlow includes integrated app support functionality, enabling you to receive on -demand 
assistance during your daily operations and use of the ArcFlow system. ArcFlow engineers will 
provide real -time support through messaging, screen sharing, and audio fe atures, ensuring your 
operations continue smoothly without disruptions.  
 • In-App Support  
In-App Support Functionality  
 
 
Company Wide Virtual Training  
Should you wish to arrange a comprehensive virtual software training session for your entire 
company, we encourage you to reach out using the direct contact information provided below. 
Our team will work with you to schedule a convenient meeting date and t ime that aligns with 
your organisations needs and availability. We look forward to assisting you in optimising your 
team's proficiency with our software solution.  
 • Company Contacts  
Contact 1: Sam Burditt

ability to streamline operations and enhance efficiency and productivity.

• The system offers automation capabilities through real time flow of data 
between the different modules. Whilst going through the training documentation, diagrams are 
provided to outline the workflows and flow of data between the different modules and su b 
modules.

 • ArcFlow Workflow and Module Dependancy  
 • High Level ArcFlow Workflow Overview  
 • The descriptions and diagram below illustrate the workflows that the system 
uses to support your daily manufacturing operations. Each workflow occurs within the listed 
modules, and once a workflow is completed within one module, it seamlessly transition s to the 
next module in the process.  
 • The description outlines the entire process, starting from loading products, 
assemblies, and items onto the system and creating their manufacturing routes. With these 
routes established, you can create sales orders and production orders, as well as init iate the 
ordering of necessary stock.  
 • After production orders are completed, the process outlines the steps from 
fulfillment to customer delivery, ensuring a smooth transition from production to final delivery.  
 • High Level ArcFlow Workflow Process  
 • Process 1: Blueprints and Routing  
 • You will begin by loading your items, assemblies, and products onto the system. 
After this, you will create the Bill of Materials (BOM) structures for these assemblies and 
products. Next, you can add stock values into your warehouse, which will integrat e with the 
production and ordering processes.  
 • Once the BOM structures are in place, you can establish the manufacturing 
routes for the assemblies and products. With these routes created, you can then develop 
production plans for the assemblies and routes.  
 • Finally, after these steps are completed, you can add the sellable items, 
assemblies, and products to sales quotes and create sales orders.

• Process 2: Customers and Sales Orders  
 • You can quote customers and create sales orders for sellable items, assemblies, 
and products from your blueprints library. Once a customer accepts a quote, you can generate a 
sales order, which is then transferred to the production team via the manufact uring module to 
develop a production plan.  
 • Process 3: Production Orders  
 • You can now create production orders to fulfill your sales order. The system will 
calculate any stock shortfalls and notify the procurement department to create an order plan 
for the required raw materials. If sufficient stock or finished sellable items  are available, the 
system will account for this accordingly.  
 • Process 4: Suppliers and Order Plans  
 • The procurement department will be notified of the production order and 
provided with a list of items needed to complete the production plan. You will then create a 
Request for Quote (RFQ) with multiple suppliers. Once a supplier's quote is accepted, a 
purchase order will be generated. You will track the receipt of the orders and generate a Goods 
Received Note to capture the received stock.  
 • Process 5: Warehousing  
 • Once a Goods Received Note has been created, you can assign the ordered 
items to various warehouse areas, such as raw materials.  
 • When the stock is available, you can initiate production plans and start 
allocating jobs, beginning with the kitting process.  
 • The warehouse also functions as temporary storage for completed sub -
assemblies during their routing process, as well as a holding area for final goods awaiting 
customer delivery.  
 • Process 6: Work Orders, Job Cards, Kitting and Production Routes  
 • Work Orders are generated from production plans to schedule the start date, 
contents, and quantities of production.  
 • Subsequently, job cards are created to commence the production process 
based on the routing of assemblies and products established in the blueprints module.  
 • The first step in the routing of assemblies or products is to kit the necessary 
items for the assembly route or assemble the products for the final route.  
 • Job cards are associated with the processes involved in converting raw materials 
into assemblies and final products.  
 • These job cards are then allocated to employees responsible for carrying out 
and completing the processes at designated workstations along your production line.  
 • Upon completion of the final route, the products are stored in either the final 
goods storage or assembly storage in preparation for customer delivery.  
 • Process 7: Storage for Customer Delivery

• Once the products are completed, they are stored in their final goods storage 
unit. Upon availability, the fulfilment team is notified to commence the picking, packing, and 
scheduling of delivery to fulfil the sales order.  
 • Process 8: Order Fulfilment and Delivery  
 • The fulfillment team will proceed to generate a picking list containing the items 
required for delivery. Once the picking process is complete, you will package the contents and 
affix the appropriate labels.  
 • Following packaging, the goods will be temporarily stored in a designated area, 
ready for either customer pickup or collection by the courier supplier for delivery to the 
customer.  
 • You can track the delivery progress using waybills to ensure successful delivery.  
 • High Level ArcFlow Workflow Diagram and Module Dependancy  
System Configuration Overview  
System Configuration Module Description:  
The "System Configuration" module encompasses essential functionalities tailored to set up 
and customize system parameters.  
You are able to setup your company information which feeds into customer, supplier and GRN 
documentation for recording and accounting keeping.  
Tax rules and regulations allow you to create different tax classes to be assigned to sellable 
items, assemblies and products. The tax class are assigned to these sellable types to different 
customers for different tax jurisdictions during the quoting and invoicing stages.  
System Configuration Process Flow:  
  
System Configuration Sub Modules:  
 • Tax Rules and Regulations  
This component provides tools for configuring tax -related parameters, including tax rates, 
jurisdictions, exemptions, and compliance requirements. Users can define tax rules based on 
regional regulations, product categories, or customer attributes, ensurin g accurate calculation 
and application of taxes across transactions. Additionally, this functionality supports updates to 
tax laws and regulations, helping businesses maintain compliance and mitigate risks.  
 
 • Company Information  
This section allows users to input and maintain vital company details such as legal entity name, 
address, contact information, and organizational structure. It serves as the foundation for 
various ERP processes, ensuring accurate representation and identifi cation of the company 
within the system.

Company Information  
Overview Description:  
The configuration for company information facilitates the input of essential company details, 
including Registered Name, Trading Name, Tax Number, Registration Number, Billing, and 
Shipping Address.  
This entered information serves to automate the inclusion of company details on system -
generated documents intended for customers, suppliers, or record -keeping purposes.

Tax Rules & Regulations  
Overview Description:  
The configuration for tax rules and regulations enables the creation of multiple tax classes, each 
designated for sellable products, assemblies, and items. These tax classes are comprised of 
several components, including Tax Rate, Collection Jurisdiction, Destination Jurisdiction, and 
the effective start date.  
Below are the definitions for each component:  
Collection Jurisdiction  
 • Definition: The specific location from which the sales transaction originates, 
typically representing the seller's business premises or the point of dispatch for the goods.  
 • Determining Factor: The seller's business address or the site from which the 
products are shipped.  
Destination Jurisdiction  
 • Definition: The location where the goods are ultimately delivered, typically 
corresponding to the buyer's location.  
 • Determining Factor: The delivery address or the buyer's business location where 
the goods are received.  
Tax Rate  
 • The tax rate is the VAT or sales tax in which you charge the buyer.  
Start Date  
 • Current Date: If you are setting up the tax class to be used immediately, you can 
use the current date.  
 • Future Date: If the tax class will apply from a specific future date (e.g., the start 
of a new fiscal period or in anticipation of a tax rate change), you should set that future date.  
 • Historical Date: If you are entering the tax class to reflect a period that has 
already begun (e.g., backdating to align with fiscal policies or corrections), you should use the 
relevant past date.

HR and Training Overview  
HR and Training Module Description  
The HR and Training Module facilitates the management of employee or contractor information 
and records within the system.  
Users can add employees or contractors as access users, granting them specific permissions to 
perform tasks within the ERP system. Alternatively, individuals can be added as non -access 
users for record -keeping purposes.  
In summary, this module serves as a comprehensive tool for managing personnel and 
resources, whether for maintaining records or assigning permissions within the ERP system.  
HR and Training Module Process Flow  
  
HR and Training Sub Modules  
 • User Management  
The ArcFlow User Management Sub Module allows admin users to create users to be loaded 
onto the system with their allocated permissions.  
You are able to create two types of users which are outlined below:  
 ◦ No Access User: User won’t need access to the platform.  
 ◦ Access User: User needs log in and access to the platform.  
 • Each type of user will have their own specified permissions and access to 
certain modules, sub modules and features when navigating and performing actions on the 
system.  
 
 
User Management  
Overview Description:  
The ArcFlow User Management Sub Module allows admin users to create users to be loaded 
onto the system with their allocated permissions.  
You are able to create two types of users which are outlined below:  
Access User

Access Users require login credentials and access to the ERP platform. They have permissions 
assigned to them based on their role and responsibilities within the organization. These 
permissions dictate what actions they can perform within the system, such as viewing, creating, 
editing, or deleting data, based on the modules and features they need to access to fulfill their 
job duties.  
No Access User  
No Access Users do not require access or assigned roles and responsibilities within the ERP 
system. They are individuals involved in your business operations but do not need direct system 
access. While you can record, pay, and track these users and interac t with them through the 
system, they do not need ERP access to carry out their daily tasks.  
Each type of user will have their own specified permissions and access to certain modules, sub 
modules and features when navigating and performing actions on the system.

Blueprints Overview  
Blueprints Module Description  
This module is where the products, assemblies and items are managed. This encompasses 
their Bill of Materials (BOM), Routing and metadata.  
The blueprints modules encompasses two sub modules being the blueprints library and the 
routing for associated products, assemblies and items.  
The library is where the database of all items, assemblies and products are managed. This 
allows for users to go through and a host of information about each of the stored entities 
including their BOM, routing, metadata and explosions (list of every item i n the entity).  
The setup of the Blueprints library and routing processes allows for warehouse stock to be 
updated, sales processes to be established, procurement cycles and enables the production 
through manufactured routes.  
BOM Process and Structure  
A bill of materials (BOM) is a comprehensive list of all the components, parts, and raw materials 
required to produce a finished Assembly or Product. It includes detailed information about each 
item, such as the part number, description, quantity, and the relationship between the 
components. The BOM serves as a reference for production planning, inventory management, 
and cost estimation. It ensures that all the necessary materials are available and that the 
production process runs smoothly.  
The BOM follows a structure as seen in the diagram below:  
  
Routing Processes and Structure  
Routing refers to the defined sequence of operations or steps that need to be followed during 
the manufacturing or production process of a product or assembly. It outlines the specific 
tasks, workstations, and resources required at each step to transform t he raw materials or 
components into a finished product. This can also include any documentation or quality 
controls required during a part of the process.  
The routes of a BOM can follow two distinct processes being manufacturing routes and sub 
contracted routes.  
The high level overview of the assembly or product route is found below and elaborated further 
on the “Routing” training folder:  
  
Blueprints Module Process Flow  
  
Blueprints Sub Modules  
 • Library

The library is where the database of all items, assemblies and products are stored. This allows 
for staff to go through and a host of information about each of the stored entities including their 
BOM, routing, metadata and explosions (list of every item in  the entity).  
 
 • Routing  
Routing refers to the defined sequence of operations or steps that need to be followed during 
the manufacturing or production process of a product or assembly. It outlines the specific 
tasks, workstations, and resources required at each step to transform t he raw materials or 
components into a finished product. This can also include any documentation or quality 
controls required during a part of the process.  
 
Library  
Library Overview Description:  
The Blueprints module facilitates the digital creation of your manufacturing company's Items, 
Assemblies, and Products.  
This module allows you to meticulously define and create isolated items, assemblies, and 
products, each with their key information and attributes. These attributes seamlessly integrate 
into and support various processes regarding ordering, sales, manufactu ring, and storage of the 
created items, assemblies and products.  
Additionally, the Blueprints module facilitates the creation of Bill of Materials (BOM) structures 
for assemblies and products. This step is crucial as it establishes the foundation for the 
manufacturing routes needed to produce the specified structures.  
By leveraging the Blueprints module, you ensure a cohesive and efficient workflow from the 
initial creation of components to the final production stages.  
Definitions and Key Attributes  
Item  
An item stands as the fundamental building block, situated at the lowest level of the BOM 
hierarchy within assemblies or products. These items encompass raw materials or any 
components incapable of further subdivision into smaller parts.  
The key attributes and their definitions are found below:  
 • Is Shipping Container  
If you tag an item as “Is Shipping Container” the system will store this items as a container for 
packaging completed sellable stock for customer delivery. These items will be presented in the 
fulfilment module when you need to allocate packaging materials  for customer deliveries. An 
example of this type of item will be a wooden pallet.  
 
 • Is Shipping Supplies

If you tag an Item as “Is Shipping Supplies” the system will store the item for the purposes of 
protecting sellable stock inside the shipping container. An example of this type of item would be 
bubble wrap.  
 
 • Is Sub Contracted  
If you tag an Item as “Is Sub Contacted” it means that you will not be able to directly procure 
this item. Rather, you will have to create a sub contracted route that has this item as a result.  
 
 • Supplier Conversion  
When you load an item you allocate your internal Unit of Measure. When you are linking the 
supplier which will supply a particular item, you enter in the suppliers UOM. If there is a 
difference between the conversion of your UOM to the suppliers UOM, pleas e enter the 
conversion of the single supplier UOM compared to your UOM of the item. You can enter in "1" if 
there is an exact conversion between you and your supplier.  
Eg: 
Your UOM: Box Supplier's UOM: Carton Conversion rate: 1 Carton = 10 Boxes If you need to 
order 50 Boxes of screws from your supplier, you'll first need to convert it to their unit of 
measure:  
50 Boxes * (1 Carton / 10 Boxes) = 5 Cartons  
So, you would need to order 5 Cartons of screws from your supplier to fulfill your requirement of 
50 Boxes.  
 
 • Can Sell  
If you tag an Item as “Can Sell” it means that you can directly add the item as an individual line 
item on a quote or invoice. These items will need to be stored in the finished goods warehouse 
area type.  
 
Assembly  
An assembly consists of multiple child items and additional sub -assemblies. These 
components are combined into a Bill of Materials (BOM) to create the assembly. Physically, 
assemblies are produced through a sequence of operations defined in their productio n route. 
An assembly can also be included in the BOM of a parent assembly or final product.  
The key attributes and their definitions are found below:  
 • Is Sub Contracted  
If you tag an assembly as “Is Sub Contracted” it suggests that, although there is a Bill of Material 
for producing it in -house, the entire assembly will be manufactured by an external company.

• Is Phantom  
A Phantom Assembly refers to a a group of components used temporarily in the production 
process. It is not a physical assembly, rather a virtual grouping of items for manufacturing 
convenience, bypassing inventory tracking.  
 
 • Is Manufactured In -House  
If an assembly is tagged “Is Manufactured In -House” it suggests the assembly is produced in -
house by following its routing process and associated BOM.  
 
 • Is Packaging  
The Assembly created is used for packing purposes and not directly linked to the BOM structure 
of a parent assembly or final product.  
 
 • Can Sell  
If you tag an Assembly as “Can Sell” it means that you can directly add the Assembly as an 
individual line item on a quote or invoice. These Assemblies will need to be stored in the 
finished goods warehouse area type.  
 
Product  
A product is the highest level in a Bill of Materials (BOM) structure. It is a collection of items and 
assemblies, created through a BOM. Unlike assemblies or items, a product cannot be included 
as a child in another BOM structure. Physically, products are  produced through a sequence of 
operations outlined in their routing process. Products are typically ordered by customers and 
manufactured specifically for sales.  
The key attributes and their definitions are found below:  
 • Is Sub Contracted  
If you tag a Product as “Is Sub Contracted” it suggests that, although there is a Bill of Material for 
producing it in -house, the entire Product will be manufactured by an external company.  
 
 • Is Packaging  
The product and BOM is used for packaging purposes for the delivery of additional sellable 
products.  
 
 • Is Manufactured In -House  
If a Product is tagged “Is Manufactured In -House” it suggests the Product is produced in -house 
by following its routing process and associated BOM.

• Can Sell  
If you tag a Product as “Can Sell” it means that you can directly add the Product as an individual 
line item on a quote or invoice. These Products will need to be stored in the finished goods 
warehouse area type.  
 
BOM Structure:  
  
Enabling of External Workflows  
Routing  
Once you have completed your library and BOM structures, you can create manufacturing or 
subcontracting routes for items, assemblies, and products. The routes are made up of 
processes associated with the BOM.  
Sales  
Once you have completed your library, you are able to add the items, assemblies or products 
onto sales quotes and invoices. Additionally, sales orders will be created which will feed 
production processes.  
Procurement  
Once you have completed your library, you are able to request quotes from suppliers for the 
created items, assemblies and products which then convert to purchase orders and received 
ordered items will be assigned to the warehouses.  
Warehouse Stock  
The creation of the products, assemblies and items also allows you to add stock values into the 
warehouse for the created products, assemblies and items.  
Production  
Created items, assemblies and products and their associated BOM and routes feed into the 
production processes through the completion of processes based on its route.

Routing  
Overview Description:  
The ArcFlow routing functionality is essential for planning and sequencing the operations 
needed to transform raw materials or components into finished assemblies and products.  
These established routes integrate with your internal production processes to create and 
schedule job cards for completing the associated tasks. Additionally, subcontracted routes can 
be set up to outsource the manufacturing of items, assemblies, or produc ts. 
This routing forms the foundation of production scheduling, planning, and capacity 
management.  
The ArcFlow system allows you to create routing for the following processes:  
Manufactured Assembly Routes  
Manufactured Assembly Routes consist of a series of operations carried out through your 
internal manufacturing processes to produce an assembly. These routes utilize the Bill of 
Materials (BOM) structure, which comprise of children items and assemblies, an d involve 
various processes performed by your employees at designated workstations.  
Prerequisites:  
 • The Assembly needs to be tagged with “Is Manufactured In -House”  
 • The Assembly needs a BOM Structure  
 • If there are children Assemblies part of the BOM structure, they needs to have an 
already established route.  
Manufactured Product Routes  
Manufactured Product Routes consist of a series of operations carried out through your internal 
manufacturing processes to produce a Product. These routes utilize the Bill of Materials (BOM) 
structure, which comprise of children items and assemblies, and i nvolve various processes 
performed by your employees at designated workstations.  
Prerequisites:  
 • The Product needs to be tagged with “Is Manufactured In -House”  
 • The Product needs a BOM Structure  
 • If there are children Assemblies part of the BOM structure, they needs to have an 
already established route.  
Sub Contracted Routes  
Subcontracted routes can be created for items, assemblies, and products that are not 
processed in -house. For items, subcontracted routes are necessary when direct procurement is

not possible, requiring the item to be obtained through an external manufacturing process. For 
assemblies and products, even though there is a Bill of Materials for in -house production, 
subcontracted routes mean the entire assembly or product will be manuf actured by an external 
company.  
Prerequisites:  
 • The item, assembly or product needs to be tagged with “Is Sub Contracted”  
 • You need to have created Sub Contractor services suppliers in the procurement 
module  
Assembly and Product Manufactured Route Definitions  
Each routing process comprises the following key workflows:  
 • Input: This encompasses the items or assemblies required for the process, 
which can either be the output from the preceding completed process or externally sourced 
materials.  
 • Process: This stage entails the specific operations, instructions, and tools 
necessary to execute the task or process outlined in the input stage.  
 • Output: The output represents the end results of the processed input, which 
subsequently form the final output of the process and are transferred to the subsequent 
process as inputs.  
The routing process is intricately linked to the assembly or product Bill of Materials (BOM). 
Moreover, each step within the routing process is associated with a designated workstation and 
assigned employees responsible for its execution.  
The final step of the routing process of an assembly or product is linked to a warehouse type 
storing the partial or final form of the completed assembly or product.  
Functioning as a comprehensive roadmap for the entire production process, the routing 
ensures seamless guidance for every work order, operation, and assembly step, thereby 
facilitating the timely and efficient completion of the final product.  
Additionally, the routing serves as the cornerstone for capacity planning activities once job 
cards have been assigned, aiding in the optimization of production resources and schedules.  
Sub Contracted Route Definitions  
The sub contracted routes comprises of utilising a sub contractor, which was created in the 
procurement module, to outsource the manufacturing processes.  
Each route comprises of the following key terms:  
 • Sub Contractor: A type of servicing suppliers which receives your sent items, 
assemblies or products and completes their own internal route prior to convert the received 
stock into a finished state.  
 • Sent to Sub Contractor: The items, assemblies or products sent to the sub 
contractor to be converted into its finished state.

• Instructions: A set of document instructions which outline the request of work 
performance and details to convert the received items, assemblies or products into its finished 
state.  
 • Received from Sub Contractor: The outsourced manufactured items, 
assemblies or products which have been processed through your set of instructions into the 
finished state.  
Since the route is sub contracted, you will utilise the procurement module to generate a RFQ 
and Purchase Order prior to the route being established. Once the route has been completed, 
you will receive the item, assembly or product in its finished state an d allocate them to the 
correct warehouse.

 • Create Manufacturing Product Route  
The following product route has been created to follow a two step process. The first step is to 
assemble the product and then the second step is to quality control the product. The product is 
then placed in the finished good store.  
During the walkthrough you will note the input, process and output needed at each stage of the 
process within the route.

Sales Overview  
Sales Module Description  
This module manages all aspects of the sales process, including customer relationship 
management, sales orders, invoicing, pricing, and revenue tracking. It's essential for managing 
customer interactions and sales transactions effectively. It also allows f or the effective 
management of both internal and external staff.  
Sales Module Process Flow  
  
Sales Quote: A sales quote is a document provided to a potential customer that outlines the 
estimated cost of a product or service. It includes details such as the quantity, unit price, and 
total price of the items being quoted. Sales quotes are typically used to initiate the sales 
process and provide customers with an understanding of the pricing for their desired products 
or services.  
Sales Order: A sales order is a formal request made by a customer to purchase goods or 
services. It includes specific details such as the quantity, description, and agreed -upon price of 
the items being ordered. Sales orders are generated based on the custo mer's acceptance of a 
sales quote and serve as a confirmation of the purchase.  
Fulfilment Order: A fulfilment order is created to initiate the process of fulfilling a customer's 
order. It includes information about the items to be shipped, their quantities, and any special 
instructions related to packaging or delivery. Fulfilment ord ers are typically used by warehouse 
or fulfilment teams to pick, pack, and ship the ordered items to the customer.  
Sales Invoice: A sales invoice is a document sent to the customer after the products or services 
have been delivered. It includes detailed information such as the itemized list of products or 
services provided, quantities, prices, any applicable taxes, and  the total amount due. Sales 
invoices serve as a formal request for payment and provide a record of the transaction.  
The process from a sales quote to a sales order to fulfilment and finally to a sales invoice 
involves the following steps: A sales quote is created and sent to the customer, outlining the 
estimated cost of the requested products or services. Once the custo mer accepts the quote, a 
sales order is generated, confirming the purchase.

The procurement team will create a production plan based on the sales order products, 
assemblies or items and their associated quantities. Upon production completion, the 
fulfilment team then prepares a fulfilment order, picking and packing the items for s hipment. 
After the items are delivered to the customer, a sales invoice is generated and sent to request 
payment for the completed transaction.  
Sales Sub Modules  
 • Sales Personnel  
Sales personnel are internal employees who earn either a wage or a combination of wage and 
commission to sell manufactured products to current or prospective customers.  
They have access to a personalized dashboard and are responsible for managing the sales cycle 
and customer relationships.  
Sales employees can create quotes, sales orders, sales invoices and customer within their 
allocate permissions and dashboard.  
 
 • Customer Management  
Customer management involves the creation and oversight of active, inactive, and prospective 
customer leads. Each customer has a dedicated profile and dashboard for assessing insightful 
metrics, and sales cycles can be initiated directly from their dashboa rd. 
 
 • Sales Order Management  
Sales order management is a global module which handles and oversees customer orders from 
initial quotation to final invoicing. It involves creating quotes, converting them into sales orders, 
generating invoices, and tracking the progress of purchased asse mblies, products, and items as 
they move through production. This ensures that all aspects of the sales order, from pricing and 
order details to production status and delivery schedules, are efficiently managed and 
monitored, providing a seamless experienc e for both the sales team and the customer.  
 
 • Customer Returns  
The ArcFlow Customer Return feature enables you to manage the entire return process 
efficiently. It allows customers to request return authorizations and facilitates the receipt and 
inspection of returned items. The feature supports processing refunds or r eplacements and 
updating inventory records accordingly. It also provides detailed tracking and reporting on 
return reasons and statuses, ensuring that returns are handled swiftly and accurately to 
maintain customer satisfaction.  
 
 • Sales Configurations  
The Sales Configuration module in our system allows you to set up and manage pricing 
structures, including price breaks and percentage discounts. These discounts can be assigned

to sellable products, assemblies, and individual items, or directly to specific customers. This 
flexibility enables you to create tailored pricing strategies that cater to various customer 
segments and sales scenarios, ensuring competitive and attractive p ricing for your products 
while maximizing profitability and customer satisfaction.  
 
 • Warranties  
Our warranty system enables you to efficiently manage product warranties by tracking warranty 
terms and conditions for each item sold. It allows you to register warranty details at the time of 
sale, monitor warranty periods, and handle claims and repairs. The system also supports the 
processing of replacements or refunds under warranty and provides comprehensive reporting 
on warranty claims and statuses, ensuring that both customers and internal teams have clear 
visibility and management of warranty -related activities.  
 
 • Sales History  
Our Sales History module provides a comprehensive record of all past sales transactions. It 
allows you to view detailed information on each sale, including product details, quantities, 
prices, customer information, and dates of transactions.  
 
 • Dashboard  
The Sales Dashboard sub -module on the ArcFlow ERP system provides a real -time overview of 
sales performance through visual charting and metric collection. Users can filter date ranges to 
customize the displayed data. The dashboard tracks metrics such as sa les volume, highest -
performing sellable products, assemblies, and items, and shows customer segments based on 
sales volume. This comprehensive view helps businesses quickly assess their sales activities 
and make informed decisions.  
 
Sales Personnel  
Overview Description:  
The ArcFlow Sales Personnel Sub -Module is designed for employees who earn either a wage or 
a combination of wage and commission. These sales personnel manage the relationship 
between the company and their customers, actively selling products and addressing  customer 
needs. They can initiate quotes, sales orders, and invoices, as well as monitor the status of 
order fulfillment. Additionally, they have access to personalized dashboards that enable them 
to track their performance and gain insights into their sa les trends, optimizing their sales 
activities and customer interactions.

Customer Management  
Overview Description:  
The ArcFlow Customer Management Sub -Module, customer management encompasses the 
comprehensive creation and oversight of active, inactive, and prospective customer leads. Each 
customer is assigned a dedicated profile within the system, equipped with a perso nalized 
dashboard tailored to assess insightful metrics and analytics.  
This dashboard provides valuable data on customer interactions, purchase history, and 
preferences, empowering sales personnel to make informed decisions and personalize their 
approach.  
Moreover, the integration of sales cycle initiation directly from the customer dashboard 
streamlines the process, allowing for seamless transition from lead generation to conversion. 
Through this robust module, ArcFlow enables businesses to effectively man age their customer 
relationships and drive sales growth.

Sales Order Management

Overview Description:  
Within the ArcFlow Sales Order Management Sub -Module, sales order management 
encompasses the comprehensive process of overseeing customer orders from inception to 
completion. This entails a series of steps, beginning with the creation of quotes and their 
subsequent conversion into sales orders.  
The system facilitates the seamless generation of invoices and enables the tracking of 
purchased assemblies, products, and items as they progress through various stages of 
production. By providing real -time updates on pricing, order details, production sta tus, and 
delivery schedules, the module ensures that all aspects of the sales order are efficiently 
managed and monitored. This comprehensive approach enhances transparency and 
communication between the sales team and customers, resulting in a seamless and  satisfying 
experience for both parties.  
Definitions:  
Sales Quote  
A sales quote is a document provided to a potential customer that outlines the estimated cost 
of a product or service. It includes details such as the quantity, unit price, and total price of the 
items being quoted. Sales quotes are typically used to initi ate the sales process and provide 
customers with an understanding of the pricing for their desired products or services.  
Note: During the sales cycle, you are able to skip the sales quote stage, but the initial step has 
to be the sales order. The sales order is feeder data into the manufacturing module which alerts 
the production team of up and coming orders for production.  
Sales Order  
A sales order is a formal request made by a customer to purchase goods or services. It includes 
specific details such as the quantity, description, and agreed -upon price of the items being 
ordered. Sales orders are generated based on the customer's accepta nce of a sales quote and 
serve as a confirmation of the purchase.  
Proforma Invoice  
A proforma invoice is a preliminary bill of sale sent to buyers in advance of a shipment or 
delivery of goods. It details the types and quantities of products, their prices, and other 
important terms such as delivery and payment terms, but it is not a dema nd for payment. 
Proforma invoices are commonly used to provide an estimate or quote to the buyer, allowing 
them to review and approve the details before the final invoice is issued and the transaction is 
completed. This document helps ensure transparency a nd agreement on the terms of the sale 
before the actual transaction takes place.  
Sales Invoice  
A sales invoice is a document sent to the customer after the products or services have been 
delivered. It includes detailed information such as the itemized list of products or services 
provided, quantities, prices, any applicable taxes, and the total amou nt due. Sales invoices 
serve as a formal request for payment and provide a record of the transaction.

Customer Returns

Overview Description:  
It allows customers to request return authorisations and facilitates the receipt and inspection of 
returned items. The feature supports processing refunds or replacements and updating 
inventory records accordingly. It also provides detailed tracking and re porting on return reasons 
and statuses, ensuring that returns are handled swiftly and accurately to maintain customer 
satisfaction.  
Customer Return Definitions:  
During the customer return process you will be presented with the following key terms:  
Warranty Status  
During the warranty setup and creation process you created different warranty classes which 
we assigned to sellable items, assemblies and products. When you lodge a customer return, 
you enter in the serial number of the sold good and the system checks for any linked warranties.  
You will be presented with the following warranty statuses upon serial number entry:  
 • No Warranty: There has been no warranties assigned to the sellable item, 
assembly or product. There will be no coverage for the customer.  
 • In Warranty: There has been an assigned warranty and the customer will receive 
a return or services in line with the created warranty coverage.  
 • Out of Warranty: There has been an assigned warranty, but the warranty 
expiration date has been reached and there is no longer an active warranty claim.  
Issue Date  
The Issue Date is the date in which the sellable item, assembly or product was sold or delivered 
to the customer. The issue date resembles the data in which the warranty is initiated for 
potential coverage.  
Expiration Date  
The Expiration Date is the date in which the warranty becomes inactive. This is calculated by 
adding the standard warranty duration for the assigned warranty to the date of issue outlined 
above. Any return before the expiration date will entitle warranty c overage.

Sales Configuration  
Overview Description:  
The Sales Configuration module in our system allows you to set up and manage pricing 
structures, including price breaks and percentage discounts. These discounts can be assigned

to sellable products, assemblies, and individual items, or directly to specific customers. This 
flexibility enables you to create tailored pricing strategies that cater to various customer 
segments and sales scenarios, ensuring competitive and attractive p ricing for your products 
while maximizing profitability and customer satisfaction.  
Please find the descriptions below:  
Price Breaks: A price break is a discount or reduction in the price of sellable stock based on the 
quantity purchased. Initially, price breaks are assigned to sellable stock items. They can also be 
assigned to specific customers, but only after being appli ed to the sellable stock. This 
mechanism reflects deviations in the price of an item depending on the quantity bought, 
thereby encouraging bulk purchases by offering lower prices for larger quantities.  
Percentage Discounts: A percentage discount is a reduction in the price of an item based on a 
specified percentage, applied during the sale. This type of discount can be created specifically 
for a customer, which is a required field. Once established, the percentage discount can be 
assigned to sellable stock linked to that customer. A single percentage discount is added and 
applied at the time of sale, ensuring that the customer receives the agreed -upon discount on 
their purchases.

Warranties  
Overview Description:  
The ArcFlow warranty sub -module enables the creation of specific warranty classes that can be 
assigned to various sellable products, assemblies, and items.  
This feature categorizes the coverage and details associated with a customer's returned 
product, assembly, or item. The coverage also specifies whether there is a fee or no fee charged 
to the customer for the returned order to be either replaced, repaired,  and returned.  
Key Definitions:  
During the warranty creation process you will be presented with key terms. Please find the 
definitions of each term below:  
Warranty Type

A warranty type is a classification within a system that defines the specific terms and conditions 
of a warranty provided for products, items, or assemblies. By categorizing warranties into 
different types, a business can more efficiently manage and apply the appropriate warranty 
terms to various products and ensure customers receive the correct support and service based 
on their purchase.  
Start Date  
The start date is the date in which the warranty becomes effective and the coverage is initiated. 
The system provides for warranties to become effective based on the data of sale or the date of 
delivery.  
Duration  
The duration is the amount of time in which the warranty is valid for and induces coverage of the 
sellable item, assembly or product.

Sales History  
Overview Description:  
Our Sales History module provides a comprehensive record of all past sales transactions. It 
allows you to view detailed information on each sale, including product details, quantities, 
prices, customer information, and dates of transactions. This module su pports the analysis of 
sales trends, customer purchasing behavior, and product performance over time. By offering in -

depth insights into historical sales data, the Sales History module helps you make informed 
business decisions, improve forecasting, and enhance customer relationship management.

Sales Dashboard  
Overview Description:  
The Sales Dashboard sub -module on the ArcFlow ERP system provides a real -time overview of 
sales performance through visual charting and metric collection. Users can filter date ranges to 
customize the displayed data. The dashboard tracks metrics such as sa les volume, highest -
performing sellable products, assemblies, and items, and shows customer segments based on 
sales volume. This comprehensive view helps businesses quickly assess their sales activities 
and make informed decisions.

Warehousing Overview

Warehousing Module Description  
The Warehouse Module is responsible for inventory management, including tracking stock 
levels, managing warehouse operations, and organizing the storage and distribution of goods. 
It's key for maintaining efficient inventory control and order fulfilment.  
The warehouse structure in the ERP system consists of four distinct levels: Site, Warehouse, 
Area, and Location. Users can create multiple instances of each level, which can be linked to 
their appropriate parent. After setting up the structure and allocati ng stock, users have the 
capability to transfer stock between different sites, warehouses, areas, and locations. 
Furthermore, they can receive stock items along with their quantities into the various levels of 
the warehouse structure.  
The users can make use of the inventory management system to create stock take requisitions 
to conduct a physical stock count and compare the quantities for the respective stock items, 
assemblies and products to the virtual quantities on the ERP system.

Warehousing Sub Modules  
 • Warehousing  
The warehousing sub module allows for the creation of the virtual representation of your 
physical warehousing structure. The sub module stored specific stock items, assemblies and 
products in certain and specified area types which act as feeder processes o r data into 
manufacturing processes.  
 
 • Inventory Management  
The inventory management sub module allows for the physical vs virtual stock count and the 
creation of stock take requisitions to update any stock discrepancies which storing a historical 
history of all previously created requisitions.  
 
 • Transfer History  
The transfer history sub module displays a historical record of all transferred or received stock 
items, assemblies or products into the different sites, warehouses, areas or locations.  
 
Warehousing  
Overview Description:  
The warehouse structure in the ERP system consists of four distinct levels: Site, Warehouse, 
Area, and Location. Users can create multiple instances of each level, which can be linked to 
their appropriate parent. After setting up the structure and allocati ng stock, users have the 
capability to transfer stock between different sites, warehouses, areas, and locations. 
Furthermore, they can receive stock items along with their quantities into the various levels of 
the warehouse structure.

Definitions  
Site  
The site represents the physical address or location where your warehouse or warehouses are 
situated. It typically encompasses a broader geographical area and may include multiple 
buildings or facilities.  
Warehouse  
A warehouse refers to the actual physical building or structure where goods are stored. It is 
within the site and serves as the primary storage space for inventory items. Each warehouse can 
have its own unique characteristics and layout.  
Area

An area within a warehouse serves as a designated section or zone dedicated to organizing and 
storing various types of inventories. These areas are categorized based on the specific type of 
items they hold, which may include finished goods, raw materials, sub-assemblies, scrap, and 
customer or supplier returns, among others.  
The areas have the following pre -defined area types which are utilized to store specific types of 
stock inventory for different use cases:  
 • Raw Materials: Area for storing unprocessed materials that will be used in 
manufacturing.  
 • Finished Goods: Space designated for products that have completed the 
manufacturing process and are ready for sale.  
 • Quality Inspection: Zone where items are checked for quality assurance before 
they move to the next phase of production or shipping.  
 • Shipping and Receiving: Area dedicated to the arrival of incoming goods and the 
dispatch of outgoing orders.  
 • Sub-assembly Inventory: Section for storing partially assembled products that 
require further assembly before they become finished goods.  
 • Kitting Space: Where individual items are grouped, packaged, and supplied 
together as one unit, which is essential for assembly lines.  
 • Packaging: Area where products are packaged for storage or shipment, with 
materials like boxes, bubble wrap, and tape readily available.  
 • Scrap/Waste Disposal: Designated spot for the collection of unusable by -
products or waste materials that are to be discarded or recycled.  
 • Tool Crib: Secure location where tools are stored and managed, often with 
check-in/check-out controls.  
 • Maintenance Area: Reserved for the upkeep and repair of machinery, 
equipment, and parts.  
 • Supplier Returns: Space allocated for storing items that are returned to 
suppliers due to defects, excess order, or other reasons.  
 • Customer Returns: Section for goods returned by customers that may be 
restocked, repaired, or processed in another manner.  
 • Special Storage: Area for items that require specific environmental conditions or 
security measures, such as high -value or hazardous materials.  
 • Temporary Storage: Flexible space used for short -term storage needs, often used 
for overflow or staging items for processing.  
 • Destroyed/Condemned: Area for goods that are marked to be destroyed due to 
irreparable damage or expiration.  
 • Repairs: Workspace for fixing damaged goods or equipment that can be returned 
to functional use.

Location  
A location is the most detailed and specific storage designation within an area. It pinpoints the 
exact spot where an item is stored within the warehouse. Locations can be identified using 
various methods such as bin numbers, shelf numbers, or coordinates,  and they help warehouse 
staff easily locate and retrieve items when needed.

Inventory Management  
Overview Description:  
The inventory management sub module is utilised to create stock take requisitions to conduct a 
physical stock count and compare the quantities for the respective stock items, assemblies and 
products to the virtual quantities on the ERP system.

Stock take requisitions can be created to record any stock discrepancies and update the virtual 
stock quantity balances to ensure the alignment of the physical stock quantities.  
Inventory Management Process Flow:  
  
Overview Video:  
Inv Man.mp4  
Walkthrough Documentation:  
 • Inventory Management  
Step 1  
Select the “Inventory Management” button to view the current stock levels and create stock 
take requisitions.  
  
Step 2  
The initial page will show you the current stock levels for all stock items for all warehouse sites 
and their associated warehouses, areas and locations.  
You must select the appropriate Site, Warehouse and Area into which you would like to create a 
Stock Take Requisition for.  
  
Step 3  
The specific destination will be populated with the assigned stock items. Select the “Generate 
Stock Take Requisition” button to action the stock take.  
  
Step 4  
Specify if you would like to include serialization and batching for the Stock Take Requisition.  
  
Select the “Confirm” button  
  
Step 5  
The Stock Take Requisition and been created and now you must select the “Stock Take 
Requisition” tab to view the pending requisitions.  
  
Step 6  
Select the specific Stock Date Code you would like to complete:

Step 7  
Select the edit button next to each item code to enter in the correct stock values:  
  
  
Step 8  
Select the "Submit Requisition” button to submit the updated quantities.  
  
The stock take requisition will now be completed and then stock values will be updated in the 
specified location.  
  
 
Transfer History  
Overview Description:  
The Transfer History sub -module meticulously records the entire history of stock transfers 
within the system. These stock transfers encompass movements between various sites, 
warehouses, areas, or specific locations within the organizational framework. Add itionally, any 
stock received from suppliers and subsequently transferred from the receivable holding area to 
a designated warehouse is comprehensively documented within this module. This thorough 
record-keeping mechanism ensures transparency and accountab ility in the inventory 
management process, providing a detailed trail of stock movements for analytical purposes and 
operational insights.

Transfer History.mp4  
Walkthrough Documentation:  
 • Transfer History

transferred or received into a specific warehouse destination:  
  
Step 2  
A full history of all receipts and transfers will be populated with the stock items associated 
code, version, type, manufacturing batch number, manufacturing serial number, internal batch 
number, internal serial number, quantity, the warehouse it was trans ferred from and the 
destination warehouse along with the data in which the transfer or receipt occurred.

\Procurement Overview  
Procurement Module Description  
This module is dedicated to the acquisition of goods and services, encompassing the 
management of supplier relationships, purchase orders, inventory levels, goods receiving, and 
invoice processing. It plays a vital role in ensuring that a business maintain s the necessary 
materials and resources to sustain its operations.  
The procurement module facilitates the creation and oversight of suppliers, subcontractors, 
and manufacturers involved in the procurement process of ordered items. Users can generate 
material orders to maintain accurate inventory levels for minimum stock r equirements, demand 
forecasting, or to fulfill production plans.  
Furthermore, the module enables the tracking and management of order plans through the 
creation and administration of RFQs (Request for Quotation) and Purchase Orders. Additionally, 
it provides functionality for managing received stock, including the creat ion of Goods Received 
Notes and the allocation of ordered items to specific warehouses.  
Procurement Module Process Flow  
  
Procurement Sub Modules  
 • Create Material Order  
The Create Material Order sub -module enables the development of order plans for purchasing 
items from suppliers. You can create material order plans based on various criteria, such as 
Order to Stock, ArcAI recommendations, Replenish Minimum Stock levels, o r the requirements 
of a production order.  
 
 • Manage Order  
The Manage Orders sub -module streamlines the administration of created order plans. It allows 
you to track progress, generate and manage RFQs and Purchase Orders, and oversee the receipt 
of ordered items, ensuring they are assigned to specific warehouses a s needed.  
 
 • Vendors/Manufacturers  
The Vendors/Manufacturers sub -module provides comprehensive tools for creating and 
managing your network of suppliers, subcontractors, and manufacturers. This module allows 
you to maintain detailed profiles for each vendor, including contact information, p roducts or 
services offered, and historical performance data.  
 
 • Dashboard

The Procurement Dashboard in the ArcFlow ERP system is a comprehensive management tool 
that provides a detailed overview of your procurement activities. It tracks key metrics such as 
procurement volume, supplier performance, and open and pending order plan s. 
 
 
Create Material Order  
Overview Description:  
The Create Material Order Plan functionality enables the development of order plans for a list of 
items and their respective quantities. These order plans are essential for ensuring stock 
availability for inventory management or production purposes. Once c reated, order plans serve 
as the basis for generating RFQs (Requests for Quotations) and, subsequently, Purchase 
Orders.  
Order Plan Creation Types:  
The system supports four different type of materials order plan creation methodologies listed 
below:  
Order to Stock  
Order to Stock involves manually creating an order plan for maintaining stock levels. This 
process allows you to select items, assemblies, and products. If you choose an assembly or 
product, the system will automatically decompose the Bill of Materials (BO M) structure into its 
individual components.  
ArcAI  
ArcAI generates a list of items and their respective quantities to be included in an order plan. 
The system leverages multiple data inputs, such as demand, minimum stock holding, delivery 
duration, and over 40 additional data sets, to provide these suggest ions.  
Production Plan  
During the production plan creation phase, the production manager can notify the procurement 
department to create a procurement order plan to meet the production plan's requirements for 
the necessary stock of assemblies and products. This allows for the di rect creation of an order 
plan based on the specific needs of the production order.  
Replenish Minimum Stock  
The Replenish Minimum Stock functionality notifies you when an order plan needs to be created 
to maintain the minimum stock levels for items. The system suggests quantities to order based 
on the difference between the current stock levels and the establish ed minimum stock quantity.

 • Replenish Minimum Stock  
 
Manage Orders  
Overview Description:  
The “Manage Orders” Sub Module serves as a comprehensive platform for creating and 
overseeing the entire life cycle of material order plans within the procurement process. 
Beginning with the initiation of quotes, this module empowers users to create purcha se orders 
seamlessly, ensuring the procurement of necessary goods or services. As the ordered stock 
items are received, the module facilitates their efficient allocation, streamlining the process of 
replenishing inventory and optimizing warehouse managemen t. 
Definitions  
Order Plan  
An order plan is a comprehensive framework that consolidates ordered items, quantities, and 
linked suppliers, serving as the backbone of the procurement process. It facilitates the creation 
of quotes and purchase orders, streamlining procurement workflows and ensuring precise 
inventory management.

RFQ  
A quote serves as a formal request sent to suppliers to assess pricing, availability, and delivery 
timelines for specific goods or services. It enables organizations to gather essential information 
from multiple suppliers before making a procurement decisi on. With the ability to create 
multiple quotes for the same ordered items from different suppliers, organizations can compare 
offers and negotiate terms to secure the most favorable deal. Additionally, the option to skip the 
quote stage and proceed directl y to creating a purchase order based on existing order plans 
streamlines the procurement process, expediting the acquisition of needed items or services.  
Purchase Order  
A purchase order is a formal document issued by a buyer to a supplier, specifying the details of 
the goods or services to be purchased. It outlines the quantity, price, delivery terms, and other 
relevant information agreed upon between the buyer and the su pplier. A purchase order serves 
as a legally binding contract between the buyer and the supplier, confirming the agreement 
reached during the procurement process.  
Receivables and Goods Received Notes  
A Goods Received Note (GRN) is a formal document acknowledging the receipt of items ordered 
as part of a purchase order. Multiple GRNs can be generated for a single purchase order. Upon 
creation of GRNs, the received stock is initially stored in the receiv ables area before being 
allocated to specific warehouses for storage, thereby updating inventory levels accordingly.

Vendors/Manufacturers  
Overview Description:  
The “Vendor/Manufacturer” Sub Module is for the management and creation of suppliers, sub 
contractors and manufacturers. Each type has their own purpose on the ArcFlow system and 
feeds into different processes.  
Definitions:  
Suppliers  
Suppliers are entities from whom you can purchase goods and services directly. They provide 
the materials, components, or products required for your production processes or business 
operations. The system allows you to manage and track your orders, deliver ies, and payments 
with these suppliers, ensuring you have the necessary resources to meet your business needs.  
Sub Contractors  
Sub Contractors are specialized service providers that you can engage to perform specific tasks 
or processes as part of your overall production or project execution. Unlike suppliers who 
provide goods, sub contractors offer services such as assembly, insta llation, or maintenance. 
The ERP system helps you manage contracts, monitor the progress of subcontracted work, and 
ensure timely completion and quality standards.  
Manufacturers

Manufacturers are entities that produce items that you may need for your operations. While you 
cannot place orders directly with manufacturers through the ERP system, you can link them to 
your items for tracking purposes. This linkage allows you to monitor  the origin of your goods, 
ensuring traceability and quality control. By tracking manufacturers, you can also manage 
information about the production capabilities and certifications of the entities that produce 
your critical items.  
Ordering Type Definitions:  
The ArcFlow system allows for three separate ordering methodologies which are automated 
through the system. When you create a supplier or sub contractor, you need to select the 
ordering type. Please find the descriptions below:  
Supplier System The Supplier System method involves sending the RFQ directly to the supplier's 
procurement or ERP system through established electronic data interchange (EDI) or other 
integration means. This process allows seamless communication and data e xchange between 
your ERP system and the supplier's system. The supplier receives the RFQ in their system, 
processes it, and sends a response back to your ERP system. This method is efficient, reduces 
manual entry errors, and ensures faster processing.  
In-House Capture In -House Capture involves preparing the RFQ within your ERP system and 
manually communicating it to the supplier. After generating the RFQ, it can be exported to a 
digital format or printed and then sent via email or mail to the supplier. The supplier sends their 
quotation back via email, mail, or fax, and it is manually entered into your ERP system. This 
method is simple and suitable for suppliers without sophisticated systems, but it requires more 
manual handling.  
ArcFlow Hotlink System The ArcFlow Hotlink System utilizes a specialized platform to manage 
the sending and receiving of RFQs. After generating the RFQ within your ERP system, it is 
transmitted to the supplier through the ArcFlow platform. The supplier pro cesses the RFQ and 
responds via the same platform, with the response then integrated back into your ERP system. 
This method centralizes communication and tracking, streamlining the procurement process 
and reducing manual errors.  
Supplier and Subcontractor KPI Metrics:  
Supplier Item KPI Metrics  
Once you have created a supplier or subcontractor and have conduced multiple purchase 
orders for the items supplied by the supplier or subcontractor each item will have a KPI rating. 
The KPI rating is the performance rating for the specific item supplied b y the supplier or 
subcontractor. The rating is based on multiple input metrics such as quality, costing, delivery 
times and stock availability etc. When creating a order plan, the system will present you with 
multiple suppliers or subcontractors tied to th e specific ordered items and based on their KPI 
rating for the item, you are able to select the suitable supplier to send out an RFQ to.  
Supplier KPI Metrics  
The supplier KPI metrics tab will be presented once you have created a supplier or 
subcontractor and have run through multiple purchase orders. Our system will present an 
analytics tab found under “Supplier KPI Metrics” when viewing a supplier and subcontr actor. 
The analytics will present metrics on Delivery Score, Quality Score, Quantity Score, Costing

Score, Responsiveness Score and Present a supplier confidence interval to suggest the overall 
confidence for the supplier.

Dashboard  
Overview Description:  
The Procurement Dashboard on the ArcFlow system offers a comprehensive overview of your 
procurement activities through detailed metrics and visualizations. It tracks key metrics such as 
procurement volume categorized by paid, pending, and settled invoices.  The dashboard 
includes dynamic charts and graphs that illustrate procurement volume trends over time, as

well as detailed breakdowns of procurement by item and by supplier. This intuitive visualisation 
aids in monitoring spending patterns, identifying top suppliers, and managing invoice statuses, 
thereby enhancing your overall procurement efficiency and decis ion-making process.

Manufacturing Overview  
Manufacturing Module Description  
The manufacturing module enables the setup of your production facility by establishing 
production lines and workstations.  
You can create production plans that are scheduled using work orders. Job cards can be 
generated and assigned to employees, who will receive tasks based on the linked processes of 
the assemblies' and products' routes.  
This module streamlines manufacturing operations by allowing users to kit assemblies and final 
assemblies before production. Additionally, users can view and execute their daily tasks or 
processes derived from the scheduled production plans.  
Manufacturing Sub Module Functionality Overview

Manufacturing Module Process Flow  
  
Manufacturing Sub Modules  
 • Production Setup  
The pre-production sub -module manages the initiation of production orders, which can 
originate from Sales Orders, Made to Stock requests, or ArcAI suggestions. It serves as the 
primary phase of the production workflow, where the generation of production or ders initiates 
the subsequent processing stages within the production sub -module.  
 
 • Pre Production  
The production sub -module streamlines the oversight of generated production orders. Initially, 
scheduling production orders is executed through works orders and job cards, supported by our 
capacity planning feature. Additionally, the production sub -module provides a live overview of 
scheduled production orders, along with their associated assemblies and products, as they 
progress through production lines and linked workstations.  
 
 • Production Operations  
The post-production sub -module facilitates the handling of finished products requiring packing 
and dispatch, destined for either warehouse storage or customer delivery.  
 
 • Production Overview  
The production history sub module gives a historical view and management of all completed 
production orders.  
 
 • Dashboard  
The manufacturing dashboard gives real time insight and decision making capabilities on the 
current production process and future production considerations.  
 
Production Setup  
Overview Description:  
A production facility is the virtual representation of the physical space where manufacturing 
processes take place. It typically includes a production floor, equipped with machinery, tools, 
and workstations organized into production lines.  
At its core, a production facility serves as the operational hub where raw materials are 
transformed into finished products or assemblies. It hosts various manufacturing processes, 
such as assembly, fabrication, machining, and quality control checks.

Production facilities comprise various production lines, each tailored to specific manufacturing 
processes. Within these production lines, there are multiple workstations, each designated for 
distinct tasks and operations. This hierarchical structure ensur es that different stages of 
production are efficiently organized and managed.  
Each workstation plays a critical role in the overall production line, contributing to the seamless 
flow of materials and assembly of products. By segmenting the production facility into 
specialized lines and workstations, the facility can optimize workflo w, enhance productivity, 
and maintain high standards of quality control throughout the manufacturing process.  
Production Setup Representation  
Once you have setup your production facility, production line and workstations, the setup will 
create a virtual production facility environment. A visual example is found below:  
  
Key Terms:  
Workstation production capacity refers to the maximum number of concurrent processes that 
can be performed. For instance, if a workstation has a production capacity of 2, this could mean 
either one employee can handle two processes simultaneously, or it co uld mean two 
employees can work on a single process concurrently.  
The production capacity directly relates to the number of employees working concurrently at a 
workstation or the number of processes that can be executed simultaneously.

Pre Production  
Overview Description:  
The Pre-Production module encompasses all workflows and activities that take place before the 
commencement of actual production. This module is designed to help you efficiently create 
detailed production plans and schedules, which are managed through the g eneration of work 
orders and job cards. By providing a structured approach to planning, the module ensures that 
all necessary preparations are in place before production begins.  
In addition to planning and scheduling, the Pre -Production module offers robust tracking 
capabilities, allowing you to monitor the progress of your production plans in real -time. This 
feature enables you to oversee the status of each planned task, identify  any potential delays or 
issues, and make necessary adjustments to keep the production process on track. Through its 
comprehensive planning and tracking functionalities, the Pre -Production module ensures that 
your production operations are well -coordinated  and poised for success.  
Definitions:  
Create Production Plan Type  
When creating a production plan you can utilise the four method listed below:  
 • Sales Order: You create a production plan based on sales orders generated by 
the sales department to fulfil a customer order.  
 • Make to Stock: You create a production plan for the purposes of increasing your 
stock holding for assemblies and products.

• ArcAI: The ArcFlow system suggests which assemblies and products and their 
associated quantities you should produce based on production forecasting.  
 • Able to Manufacture: The system alerts you on which assemblies and products 
you are able to manufacture based on your stock availability.  
Production Plan  
A production plan is developed from sales orders and made -to-stock requirements. It outlines 
the overall strategy and schedule for manufacturing products, specifying what needs to be 
produced, in what quantities, and by when, to meet customer demands and m aintain optimal 
inventory levels.  
Work Order  
A work order is generated to execute the production plan. You can have multiple work orders 
linked to a production plan. It contains the schedule and the different assemblies and products 
and their associated quantities which need to be executed. Work orde rs guide the production 
process, ensuring that each step is carried out according to the plan.  
Job Card  
Job cards are created to schedule and manage work orders. You can create multiple job cards to 
fulfil a work order. They are assigned to employees and detail the specific tasks they need to 
perform as part of the assembly or product route. Job cards help i n organizing the workflow, 
tracking progress, and ensuring that each task is completed efficiently and accurately.

Production Operations  
Overview Description:  
The Production Operations Sub Module is an operational tool utilised by the factory floor 
workers during the production process.  
It facilitates the kitting of assemblies and final assemblies prior to embarking on their 
manufactured routes for either as an assembly or product.  
Users are able to view their jobs allocated to them, the instructions for the process linked to the 
job and also the workstations in which are assigned to to complete the job.  
Definitions  
Sub Assembly Kitting Area  
The Sub Assembly Kitting Area marks the beginning of an assembly's journey along its route. 
Here, users can access a comprehensive list of all the items required for assembly, enabling 
them to gather and group these components efficiently to progress throu gh the sub assembly 
route.

Final Assembly Kitting Area  
The Final Assembly Kitting Area marks the beginning of the final assemblies journey along its 
route. Here, users can access a comprehensive list of all the items and assemblies required for 
the final assembly, enabling them to gather and group these compon ents efficiently to progress 
through the final assembly route.  
Note: before any assemblies and products can be initiated through their route using job cards, 
you will need to action the sub assembly and final assembly kitting areas before the 
components are pushed through to production. Essentially, step 1 of every pr oduction process 
is to kit the sub assembly or final assembly so all the necessary components are gathered prior 
to the production processes and routing.  
Jobs  
Jobs are created and assigned to employees which form part of a Work Order. These jobs are 
directly associated with particular processes that must be executed as part of the 
manufacturing route for an assembly or product.  
Workstations  
A workstation is a designated area within a production line where employees gather to perform 
their assigned tasks and related processes.  
Processes  
A Process is associated with a job card, detailing tasks for an employee to carry out. These 
processes occur at workstations and involve three main stages: Input, Process, and Output. The 
Input comprises the collection of items or assemblies, while the Pro cess entails utilizing 
instructions and tools to transform the Input into an Output. This Output represents the 
completed task, which subsequently serves as the Input for the next process along the 
manufacturing route for the assembly or product.

Production Overview  
Overview Description:  
The Production Overview Sub -Module serves as a comprehensive management tool, enabling 
you to monitor the real -time status of work -in-progress across various aspects of your 
production operations. This includes tracking the activities of employees, the per formance and

utilization of workstations, and the current state of assemblies and products in the 
manufacturing process.  
One of the key features of this sub -module is its ability to provide a detailed, real -time snapshot 
of ongoing production activities. Managers can observe the progress of tasks assigned to 
employees, assess the efficiency and capacity of workstations, and follow the assembly and 
production stages of products. This real -time insight helps in making informed decisions, 
identifying bottlenecks, and ensuring that production schedules are adhered to.  
Additionally, the Production Overview Sub -Module offers a comprehensive historical view of all 
manufactured assemblies and products. This historical data allows for thorough analysis and 
review of past production runs, facilitating continuous improvement a nd optimization of 
manufacturing processes.
