Dashboard  
Overview Description:  
The ArcFlow manufacturing dashboard provides both real -time and historical views of key 
manufacturing performance metrics. The dashboard features comprehensive metrics and 
charting capabilities, allowing you to track production volumes, failure rates, risk  profiles, and 
outputs from employees and workstations. Additionally, it offers capacity analysis to ensure 
optimal utilization of resources and to identify potential bottlenecks in the production process.  
Walkthrough Documentation:  
 • Manufacturing Dashboard  
Fulfilment Overview  
Fulfilment Module Description  
The Fulfilment module oversees the processing of customers' completed sales orders, 
encompassing picking, packing, and customer delivery. Here are the five steps involved in this 
process:  
 • Completed Sales Orders: Real -time visibility into the progress of picking, 
packing, and customer delivery is provided through completed sales orders.  
 • Picking Slip Generation: Picking slips are generated, detailing the sellable 
products, assemblies, and quantities for warehouse staff to pick from inventory.  
 • Boxing and Labels: Selected products, assemblies, and items are packed into 
boxes and labeled for identification and shipping purposes.  
 • Holding Area: Packed boxes are temporarily housed in a designated area for final 
checks and verification before shipment.

• Shipping: Verified orders are dispatched for customer delivery, facilitated by 
shipping labels and accompanying documentation.  
Fulfilment Module Process Flow  
  
Fulfilment Sub Modules  
 • Fulfilment  
The Fulfilment module oversees the processing of customers' completed sales orders, 
encompassing picking, packing, and customer delivery.  
 
 • Fulfilment History  
The fulfilment history provides a record of all completed orders, detailing their processing 
journey from order receipt to delivery. It offers insights into order status, tracking information, 
and any actions taken during the fulfilment process, serving as  a valuable reference for tracking 
order progress and resolving any issues that may arise.  
 
Fulfilment  
Overview Description:  
The Fulfilment module oversees the processing of customers' pending and completed sales 
orders, encompassing picking, packing, and customer delivery.  
Processes and Definitions:  
Pending and Completed Sales Orders  
Real-time visibility into the progress of picking, packing, and customer delivery is provided 
through completed sales orders.  
Picking Slip Generation  
Picking slips are generated, detailing the sellable products, assemblies, and quantities for 
warehouse staff to pick from inventory.  
Boxing and Labels  
Selected products, assemblies, and items are packed into boxes and labeled for identification 
and shipping purposes.  
Holding Area  
Packed boxes are temporarily housed in a designated area for final checks and verification 
before shipment.  
Shipping  
Verified orders are dispatched for customer delivery, facilitated by shipping labels and 
accompanying documentation.

Establishing Packaging Materials:  
During the fulfilment process you need to box the completed goods to be delivered to your 
customers. This will entail having packaging materials available for packaging purposes. You 
will create these items through the blueprints module by either creating an assembly or items 
and tag them with the following attributes:  
Is Shipping Container  
If you tag an item as “Is Shipping Container” the system will store this items as a container for 
packaging completed sellable stock for customer delivery. These items will be presented in the 
fulfilment module when you need to allocate packaging materials  for customer deliveries. An 
example of this type of item will be a wooden pallet.  
Is Shipping Supplies  
If you tag an Item as “Is Shipping Supplies” the system will store the item for the purposes of 
protecting sellable stock inside the shipping container. An example of this type of item would be 
bubble wrap.  
Once you have created these assemblies or items and added stock quantity to your appropriate 
warehouses, they will then be populated during the “Box and Label” process in fulfilment. You 
are not able to box and label if you do not have sufficient stock on hand.

Fulfilment History  
Overview Description:  
The Fulfilment History sub -module provides a comprehensive historical overview of all your 
fulfilled orders.  
Within this sub -module, you can meticulously track orders and their associated details, offering 
valuable insights into your fulfilment process. You will be able to view critical information such 
as the Sales Order Number, Date of Shipment, and Date of Arr ival. Additionally, it includes 
details about the different shipping partners involved and the corresponding waybill numbers 
linked to each delivery. This level of detail allows you to monitor and analyse your fulfilment 
operations effectively, ensuring yo u have a clear understanding of your order delivery history 
and performance.  
Overview Video:  
FulHistory.mp4  
Walkthrough Documentation:  
 • Fulfilment History  
Step 1  
Select the “Transfer History” button to view a history of all the stock and associated data 
transferred or received into a specific warehouse destination:  
  
Step 2  
A full history of all receipts and transfers will be populated with the stock items associated 
code, version, type, manufacturing batch number, manufacturing serial number, internal batch 
number, internal serial number, quantity, the warehouse it was trans ferred from and the 
destination warehouse along with the data in which the transfer or receipt occurred.

Document Hub Overview  
Document Hub Module Description  
The ArcFlow "Document Hub" serves as a centralized document repository for viewing and 
managing all documents uploaded onto the system, pertaining to various actions such as:  
 • Items  
 • Assemblies  
 • Products  
 • Node Items  
 • Suppliers  
 • Customers  
 • Manufacturers  
 • Subcontracted Routes  
 • Sales Persons  
 • GRN Delivery Notes  
 • Warranties

 • AI Functionality Overview  
 • AI Functionality Description  
 • ArcFlow leverages AI technology to enhance manufacturers' productivity with 
existing resources. By automating repetitive tasks, the system optimizes resource allocation 
and enhances decision -making efficiency.  
 • The AI models leverage over 100 input data points, which are stored, analyzed, 
and processed to generate outputs that support accurate decision -making. These models 
improve over time as more transactions occur and historical data accumulates, allowing f or 
continuous training and enhancement of the models' accuracy.  
 • At its core, ArcFlow offers three AI -driven features: Supplier KPI and Selection, 
Order Plan Automation, and Production Order Automation.  
 • AI Model Diagram  
 • The AI model comprises of:  
 • Input Parameters: the raw data sets which are fed into the Input Layers.  
 • Input Layer: Extracts the meaningful and relevant data from the Input 
Parameters.  
 • Hidden Layers: Analyses the data and their respective importance weighting and 
adjustments overtime into the AI model to create accurate AI model outputs.  
 • AI Output: The results of the computations to create an accurate suggestive 
output.  
 •   
 • AI Functionality Features:  
 • Supplier KPI and Selection  
Streamline and automate supplier selection decisions during the procurement process.

• Order Plan Automation  
Automating the order plan creation for optimal quantities and timing for ordering specific 
materials.  
 
 • Production Order Automation  
Automating production order creation and scheduling for different products and assemblies 
with their associated quantities.  
 
Supplier KPI and Selection  
Overview Description:  
The Suppliers KPI and Selection model evaluates supplier performance based on various 
metrics such as the quality of items supplied, overall performance, delivery efficiency, and cost. 
These KPI metrics are integrated into a supplier selection model, which  helps the system 
recommend the best suppliers to order from during the quoting and purchase order stages, 
considering specific constraints.

Module Dependancy Overview  
ArcFlow Interconnected and Module Dependancy Overview  
The interconnected nature of the ArcFlow system ensures a smooth flow of data across its 
various modules. This connectivity paves the way for heightened automation and more efficient 
workflows within the system.  
In this current overview, we'll delve into the dependencies between different modules and 
provide insights into how users should navigate and anticipate the completion of workflow 
processes.  
Module Dependancy Focus Points:  
 • Production and Routing

The production of assemblies and products depends on creating eligible routes for each 
assembly and product. After creating your items, assemblies, and products in the blueprints 
module, you must establish their manufacturing routes.  
 
 • Warehouse Stock, Kitting and Job Cards  
When initiating a production process by creating a production plan, there are two key 
dependencies that must be addressed before a job card can be initiated by a system user who 
has access to the “Manufacturing Operations” Sub Module.  
 
 • Warehousing and Fulfilment  
The fulfillment module handles the picking, packing, and dispatch of customer deliveries. To 
ensure smooth operations, all stock intended for delivery must be stored in a Finished Goods 
area.  
 
Routing and Production  
Overview Description:  
The production of assemblies and products depends on creating eligible routes for each 
assembly and product. After creating your items, assemblies, and products in the blueprints 
module, you must establish their manufacturing routes.  
A product comprises multiple child assemblies and items, with each child assembly having its 
own BOM (Bill of Materials) structure, including further child assemblies and items. Each level 
of an assembly's BOM structure requires a manufacturing route, whic h then integrates into the 
higher-level route of the products it is linked to.  
The routing of a product begins with manufacturing all sub -assemblies according to their 
respective manufacturing routes. Once these assemblies are manufactured, they become 
inputs for the product's manufacturing route, continuing until the finished produc t is complete.  
It is crucial to note that you cannot manufacture an assembly or product without an established 
manufacturing route.  
Overview Video:  
Routing and Production.mp4  
Warehouse Stock, Kitting and Job Cards  
Overview Description:  
When initiating a production process by creating a production plan, there are two key 
dependencies that must be addressed before a job card can be initiated by a system user who 
has access to the “Manufacturing Operations” Sub Module.

Job cards are dependent on the kitting processes for sub -assemblies or final assemblies. A user 
cannot start a job card if the items or assemblies required for the job are not kitted and pushed 
to production.  
In the kitting module, users will see a list of items and assemblies to be kitted for a specific 
manufacturing route and its associated job cards. Kitting can only proceed if there is sufficient 
stock available in the warehouse for the required items or as semblies.  
Essentially, warehouse stock is needed for kitting, and job cards can only be initiated once the 
necessary materials have been kitted. During the assembly route, the process concludes with 
storing the assembly in the appropriate Sub Assembly Warehouse. Thi s sub-assembly stock, 
once the route is completed, will then be used in the final assembly kitting area for the 
product's final production processes which is then stored in the Finished Goods Warehouse.  
Inter Connectivity Diagram:  
  
Warehousing and Fulfilment  
Overview Description:  
The fulfillment module handles the picking, packing, and dispatch of customer deliveries. To 
ensure smooth operations, all stock intended for delivery must be stored in a Finished Goods 
area.  
During the picking process, the fulfillment module only checks stock availability in the Finished 
Goods warehouse. At the end of the production process, finished goods are stored in this 
warehouse, marking the completion of the process.  
However, there are unique situations to consider. If you have an item or assembly that is 
sellable but currently stored in an Item Warehouse or Sub -Assembly Warehouse, you must 
transfer this stock to the Finished Goods area to fulfill customer orders.  
Even if an item or assembly is sellable, if it is not stored in the Finished Goods area, the system 
will not recognize its availability during the fulfillment stage, and you will be unable to process 
the delivery. Therefore, ensure all sellable stock is tr ansferred to the Finished Goods area before 
fulfillment.

Warehouse and Fulfilment.mp4  
Overview and Documentation Templates  
ArcFlow Automated Document Generation Overview  
During manufacturing operations and processes, ArcFlow captures essential information from 
customers, suppliers, employees, stock, and sellable items, as well as assemblies and 
products. This system meticulously records and organizes data, ensuring all cri tical aspects of 
production are monitored and documented. By automating the generation of necessary

documentation, ArcFlow streamlines workflow and reduces the administrative burden on your 
team. This automation ensures accuracy and efficiency, allowing you to focus more on core 
business activities while maintaining comprehensive records.  
The following documents are generated below:  
Procurement  
 • Request for Quotation with Online Review Button  
 • Request for Quotation without Online Review Button  
 • Purchase Orders  
 • Goods Received Note  
Blueprints  
 • Assemblies  
 • Products  
Manufacturing  
 • Picking Slip  
 • Packing Slip  
Sales  
 • Sales Quotation with Discount  
 • Sales Quotation without Discount  
 • Sales Order with Discount  
 • Sales Order without Discount  
 • Proforma Invoice with Discount  
 • Proforma Invoice without Discount  
 • Sales Invoice with Discount  
 • Sales Invoice without Discount  
 • Picking Slip  
 • Packing Slip  
 • Customer Return  
Storage of Documents  
The storage of all of the auto generated documents are found under the “Document Hub” 
module. Generated documents will be categorised and stored in the document repository for 
tracking and viewing purposes.
